channel.title: aws on Jente Hidskes' website
channel.description: Recent content in aws on Jente Hidskes' website

item.title: Streaming a file from S3 to SFTP on AWS Lambda using Haskell
item.description: At work we embrace the serverless computing model and (typed) functional programming. My team’s Haskell service is therefore built upon, amongst others, AWS S3 and AWS Lambda. Earlier I wrote about how we deploy our Haskell binaries on AWS Lambda. Today I will write about something at a somewhat higher level. Let’s dig in! The functional programming style encourages you to break down your problem into smaller problems. Smaller problems are easier to comprehend and reason about, and by decomposing your problem this way you often end up with a more general solution.

item.title: The Shiba project üêï
item.description: It’s a cool Saturday evening here in Stockholm. I’m sitting on the balcony with my new best friend by my side and a cool beer on the table. I just spun down a project that I hinted to over a year ago. Now’s a good time to reflect on it and explain what it was. Spoiler: it has to do with my new best friend here. In Sweden, buying a puppy is a well-controlled process.

item.title: Deploying a Nixified Haskell binary on AWS Lambda
item.description: For a current project (which I will be writing about soon!), I need to deploy a Haskell binary to AWS Lambda. Thankfully, there is a great library out there that allows Haskell code to interface with AWS Lambda. Unfortunately, Haskell is not officially supported so I needed to jump through some hoops in order to run my code. In this post I describe the process I followed to make this work.
